captions.text:
>> Jon: WELCOME TO THE DAILY
SHOW. MY NAME IS JON STEWART.

WE HAVE A VERY, VERY GOOD SHOW
FOR YOU TONIGHT.

BY POPULAR DEMAND, OUR GUEST
TONIGHT SOPHIE DELAUNAY THE

EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF DOCTORS
WITHOUT BOARDERS, SHE IS HERE

TONIGHT TO LOOK AT THIS
THING ON MY ANKLE.

A LOVELY COURAGEOUS INDIVIDUAL
AS THEY ALL ARE.

BUT FIRST, I WANT TO FIRST TALK
TO YOU NOW ABOUT

PROFESSIONAL FUTBOL.
THE AMERICAN BRAND.

IT HAS CERTAINLY SEEN ITS SHARE
OF CONTROVERSY THIS YEAR FROM A

GAY PLAYER THAT APPARENTLY
COULDN'T HIT HARD ENOUGH IS

TO A STRAIGHT PLAYER THAT COULD
BUT PROBABLY SHOULD NOT HAVE,

SHOULDN'T OF HIT AT ALL, REALLY.
TO A TEAM THAT ON PAPER BEFORE

THE SEASON SHOULD OF
BEEN IN THE HUNT.

I MEAN, FOR GOD'S SAKES, HE'S A
TWO TIME SUPERBOWL WINNING MVP.

DO WE HAVE AN OFFENSIVE LINE, DO
WE NOT HAVE AN OFFENSIVE LINE?

AM I THE ONLY ONE WHO THINKS THE
PREDICTION SCHEMES ARE NOT ONLY

ILL-DESIGNED BUT ALSO
HILARIOUSLY UNDEREXECUTED?

THE POINT IS THIS [BEEP] ODELL
BECKHAM JR., MAN.
OKAY.
NOT A FOOTBALL CROWD.

MORE OF A JOURNALISM CROWD.
[CHEERS AND APPLAUSE]
JOURNALISM, NO. UCB, YES.

I GIVE, BY THE WAY, THE WORST
CAREER ADVICE IN THE HISTORY.
YOU KNOW WHAT YOU SHOULD DO.

YOU SHOULD YOU DROP OUT OF
SCHOOL AND START HANGING OUT
AROUND THAT IMPROV THEATER.
THAT'S WHAT YOU SHOULD DO.
THAT'S WHAT YOU SHOULD DO, LADY.

ANYWAY MY POINT IS THIS, THERE
IS MORE FOOTBALL CONTROVERSY.

>> MEMBERS OF THE ST. LOUIS RAMS
COMING ON THE FIELD WITH AN
UNEXPECTED MESSAGE.
PUTTING THEIR HANDS UP.
DON'T SHOOT.

WHAT'S BECOME A SYMBOL OF THE
PROTESTS FOLLOWING FERGUSON.
>> Jon: SYMBOLE OF THE PROTESTS?

IT'S FOOTBALL. I'M PRETTY SURE
THEY'RE JUST GOING,

HEY FELLAS LET'S SCORE SOME
TOUCH DOWNS.

OR MAYBE THEY'RE JUST PREPARING
TO DANCE AT TEVYE'S DAUGHTER'S
WEDDING.

♪ SUBMISSION
♪ I'VE GOT NO GUN, SUBMISSION

A RARE INSTANCE OF SOCIAL
AWARENESS FROM THE NFL.

JOINING IN A COMMON SIGNAL OF
SOLIDARITY.

LIKE THAT "HUNGER GAMES" KATNISS
THREE FINGER SALUTE.

OF COURSE, OBVIOUSLY THE
DISTRICT 11 RESIDENTS WHO HELD

UP THEIR HANDS LIKE THAT WERE
IMMEDIATELY ATTACKED BY THE

POLICE, WHICH IS WHERE
OUR METAPHOR -- ALRIGHT.
ANYWAY, WHY IS THIS A BIG DEAL?

>> THE ST. LOUIS COUNTY
POLICE ASSOCIATION CALLING THE

GESTURE TASTELESS, OFFENSIVE
AND INFLAMMATORY.

THEY WANT THE NATIONAL FOOTBALL
LEAGUE TO APOLOGIZE AND TO
PUNISH THE PLAYERS.

>> TO US IT SEEMS LIKE RATHER
THAN ALLOWING WOUNDS TO HEAL

THAT THEY'RE FOLKS PICKING
AT THE SCABS.

[BOOING]
>> Jon: HOLY [BEEP].

SO THE ST. LOUIS POLICE
ASSOCIATION IS ANGRY AND

OUTRAGED TO HAVE BEEN CAUGHT
IN THIS HAIL OF GESTURES AND

FEELS THAT THE COMMUNITY WON'T
GET PAST THIS TRAGIC PANTOMINE

UNLESS SOMEONE IS
HELD ACCOUNTABLE.

THAT'S THE ANGLE THEY'RE GOING
WITH.
ALRIGHT.

ST. LOUIS RAMS COACH, JEFF
FISHER.

>> THEY WILL NOT BE DISCIPLINED
BY THE CLUB NOR WILL THEY

BE DISCIPLINED BY THE
NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE.

>>Jon: LET ME ASK YOU A
QUESTION WHEN DID NICK NOLTE
TAKE OVER THE RAMS.

YEAH, FISHER THAT WILL TEACH
YOU TO DO THE RIGHT THING!

A NOLTE JOKE. HE'S A RAGTOP
COACH.

ALRIGHT, SO I GUESS WE'VE GOT
OURSELVES AN OLD FASHION POLICE

DEPARTMENT PROFESSIONAL FOOTBALL
TEAM STAND OFF.
WHO IS GOING TO BLINK?

>> THE RAMS CHIEF OPERATING
OFFICER CALLED THE ST. LOUIS

POLICE CHIEF CALLED TO
APOLOGIZE FOR THE RAMS' HANDS UP

DON'T SHOOT GESTURE DURING
SUNDAY'S GAME.

>> Jon: OH, I THOUGHT, ACTUALLY
I THOUGHT THEY WERE NOT
GOING TO APOLOGIZE.

>> THE RAMS OFFICIAL, HOWEVER,
NOW DENIES APOLOGIZING.

HE SAYS IN PART IN NONE OF THESE
CONVERSATIONS DID I APOLOGIZE
FOR OUR PLAYERS' ACTIONS.

>> Jon: ISN'T IT INTERESTING HOW
WITNESS TESTIMONY IS SO

UNRELIABLE. WELL, HOW CAN WE,
HOW CAN WE IN ANY WAY
HOW CAN WE CLEAR THIS UP?
HOW DO WE CLEAR IT UP?

>> IN A TESTY AND BIZARRE
EXCHANGE OF TWEETS AND

STATEMENTS OVER NIGHT POLICE
CLAIM THE RAMS APOLOGIZED.
BUT THE RAMS SAID NO.

THEN THE POLICE TWEETED THE
DEFINITION OF APOLOGY INCLUDING
WORDS "EXPRESSION OF REGRET."

>> Jon: AND THEN, AND THEN THE
RAMS TWEETED

WTF POLICE? #UNFOLLOW AND THEN,
AND THEN

THE POLICE WERE ALL, THANKS
OBAMA #NOTALLCOPS. AND THEN,

AND THEN THE RAMS WERE LIKE THIS
COULD BE US, BUT YOU PLAYING.
[LAUGHING]

LISTEN, I SEE THE
CONFUSION HERE.

THE RAMS MADE THE SORRY IF YOU
WERE OFFENDED NON-APOLOGY NOBODY

EVER BELIEVES IS AN ACTUAL
APOLOGY AND INSTEAD OF REJECTING

THE NON-APOLOGY OUTRIGHT LIKE A
NORMAL GROUP, THE COPS CONFUSED

THINGS EVEN MORE ACCEPTING IT
FORCING THE RAMS TO CLARIFY

THE PASSIVE AGGRESSIVE NATURE
OF THEIR ORIGINAL NON-APOLOGY

WHICH MEANS AT LEAST FINALLY IN
THIS COUNTRY

WE'RE HAVING THE IMPORTANT
NATIONAL CONVERSATION ABOUT
SEMANTICS, WE NEED.

title: The Daily Show - American Hands Stand

comments.text:
It's interesting to watch this and read the comments now that we know that 
hands up didn't happen.  It embarrasses me to see so many on the same side 
of the political spectrum as myself, including Jon Stewart, get caught up 
in this mob mentality. Hands up is not just a lie, but a lie that 
implicates a living person in murder.  No matter how strong one feels about 
the issues of race in america, it can't possibly help the situation to come 
up with scapegoats to hold accountable no matter how much evidence comes 
out exonerating them.﻿

comments.author: Brent McInnis

comments.text:
+Brent McInnis Forsensics said it was kind of inconclusive. Which allows 
for justices, lawyers and grand jury to side with who ever they feel like. 

I saw the original forensics finding video. They couldn't prove for a fact 
about Michael Brown's story. It was too inconclusive, because of his arms 
being able to be either up and turned around or down and turned the other 
way. Or vice versa, I couldn't remember. So they were able to argue that 
into the cop's favor. All the cop needs is a inconclusive report to win. In 
Eric Garner's case, there was a lot more proof and they still won. It took 
until now when it's impossible to say the cop didn't do it.

should not fire 5+ shots at an unarmed man, that's not how the rest of the 
civilised world does it, so why the fuck is it OK in the US?

I also find it funny that the people excusing police violence and 
oppression are the same people that are so worried that someone might "take 
away our guns" and that the 2nd amendment is a necessity in order to 
prevent oppression from any government authority. Close-minded retards the 
whole bunch.﻿

comments.text:
+razumfrackle According to the US constitution, ammendment 5, no US 
official has the right to use lethal force that is not directed by 
nessecity or law. That only includes self- defence against armed 
individuals, and death penalties. The death of an unarmed citizent is not 
included in these exceptions. Such death consists a clear abuse of power, 
and is illegal constitutionally. The death of an unarmed citizen 
constitutes a clear use of unessesary force, thus it is punishable by law. 
The fact that he was charging on him is irrelevant.

when raising their weapon in Europe, while in the States, most LEOs tend to

comments.text:
+howaboutthatsuckah AG Eric Holder and I agree. You're an idiot. 
http://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/opa/press-releases/attachments/2015/03/04/doj_report_on_shooting_of_michael_brown_1.pdf 
"Wilson’s version is further supported by disinterested eyewitnesses 
Witness 102, Witness 104, Witness 105, Witness 108, and Witness 109, among 
others. These witnesses all agree that Brown ran or charged toward Wilson 
and that Wilson shot at Brown only as Brown moved toward him." "For all of 
the reasons stated, Wilson’s conduct in shooting Brown as he advanced on 
Wilson, and until he fell to the ground, was not objectively unreasonable 
and thus not a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 242."

comments.author: razumfrackle

comments.text:
+razumfrackle If you read my original comment it said "A good cop should 
not fire 5+ shots at an unarmed man, that's not how the rest of the 
civilized world does it, so why the fuck is it OK in the US?"

So, I'm not saying that what the officer did wasn't legal, I'm saying that 
law enforcement protocol in the US is beyond retarded.

Michael Brown didn't assault the officer and there's no evidence that the 
officer was even approached by Brown either. As a country, the US shouldn't 
authorize an officer to use lethal force against an unarmed man that isn't 
violent. Land of the free my ass.
comments.author: howaboutthatsuckah

comments.text:
+howaboutthatsuckah He Ha, you're a buffoon. ERIC HOLDER defended Officer 
Wilson's use of lethal force on Michael Brown. From the DOJ Report: "Under 
the law, Wilson has a strong argument that he was justified in firing his 
weapon at Brown as he continued to advance toward him and refuse commands 
to stop, and the law does not require Wilson to wait until Brown was close 
enough to physically assault Wilson."
comments.author: razumfrackle

comments.text:

civilian regardless of any evidence or arguments presented."

comments.author: Fernie Canto

comments.text:
+howaboutthatsuckah
Fun pic, but anecdotes are worthless as evidence. 

Try police protocol on when and particularly how to use firearms. If you 
find interesting differences there, by all means - that might convince me

But keep in mind, I've readily said that US police shoots faster, and given 
at least one of the reasons why that might be. The culture isn't the same - 
and the 2nd amendment is a pretty good illustration of that, as well as 
part of the reason. 

Whether US police is under-trained... is that more than just a blank 
statement? Or in reverse, is there any amount of training that is truly 
enough? 
What kind of training do you feel they need? And please don't say "Aim for 
the hand" training, or I will again tell you to stop watching movies ;).
comments.author: sorsocksfake

comments.text:
+sorsocksfake What movies? US LEOs use their guns way too liberally, and 
it's not only because of "maybe he has a gun", here's one example of the 
difference between US LEOs and other LEOs:

http://s1120.photobucket.com/user/thebackup/media/nygermany.jpg.html

US LEO training is sub-par, and it doesn't have to be that way, but US 
police is constantly under scrutiny because of their excessive use of force 
and incompetence, to a much larger extent than other law enforcement in 1st 
world countries
comments.author: howaboutthatsuckah

comments.text:
+howaboutthatsuckah
I think you shouldn't get your wisdom from movies ;). To my knowledge 
police protocol (at least around here) is that if you are to use your gun, 
then you don't fool around. Aim for the chest, and fire until the attacker 
goes down. 

Why it's so much worse in the US? My guess is that US officers are far more 
likely to grab their gun in the first place. In Europe it's a last resort. 
In the US, an officer knows his attacker may well be carrying a gun 
himself... I'd think that changes your perspective. If your attacker makes 
any gesture that looks like he's grabbing for his waistband, you make 
radical conclusions (especially if you're already beaten up). LEOs in most 
countries don't have to worry about that all the time. Indeed, it's my 
impression that in most of the world, the cops get a whole lot more 
respect, which allows them to do their job, most of the time, with minimal 
violence.

If you want that to change, you'll have to change the 2nd amendment for 
starters. That may also affect the other side I mentioned. In my country, 
people may dislike cops, but we know we depend on them as well, which also 
breeds some form of respect.
But I don't think that is likely to change. Americans love their 
freedoms... and they are willing to pay for it in blood. As it was best put:

"[W]hat country can preserve it's liberties if their rulers are not warned 
from time to time that their people preserve the spirit of resistance? Let 
them take arms. The remedy is to set them right as to facts, pardon and 
pacify them. What signify a few lives lost in a century or two? The tree of 
liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and 
tyrants. It is it's natural manure."
- Thomas Jefferson
comments.author: sorsocksfake

comments.text:
+sorsocksfake There's a difference between shooting an attacker in the 
leg(s) and emptying an entire clip into his chest and dome.

LEOs all over the rest of the world can defend themselves against unarmed 
civilians without killing them, why can't americans learn how to do it?

comments.text:
+Martin Rodgers Ok, to reply to your points:
1. Yes, I do mean well. I like to go for the truth rather than spouting my 
ideological  opinions without knowing anything about the specific event.
2. There is no mainstream "liberal media" in America, if you are referring 
only to widespread public news organizations (possibly MSNBC). Nor is there 
conservative media. Fox "News" does not contain enough facts to count as 
news, in my opinion, and in any case spouts opinions that are too far right 
to be considered mainstream conservative. CNN, ABC, etc. are not liberal. 
They may seem liberal to America, which is more conservative than the rest 
of the world, but in the grand scheme of things their bias is very slight, 
and not far enough left to be considered a definite liberal bias (although 
MSNBC is trying to do that; we'll say they are a liberal bias for the sake 
of fairness).
3. "Obama is a phony... and Sharpton too..." What does Obama have to do 
with this shooting? Obama denounced the protesters and told them to take 
legitimate action instead of rioting. He is, by chain of command, in charge 
of all police officers! (You'll get all states-rightsy but it's true) As 
far as Sharpton goes, I don't think anyone argues that he is extreme and 
not always helpful for race relations. True, he provides useful input for 
racial discussions and speaks for a large minority in the White House. But 
personally I think that his position could be better filled. Either way, 
I'm not sure how either of them "being phony" has anything to do with this, 
or even what that means.
4. Yes, there is a hood mentality. It is good to recognize that. We NEED to 
recognize that and provide assistance to these people. Impoverished by 
centuries of slavery and racial oppression, white people have created a 
culture for many, many black people that is uneducated, violent, and in 
poverty. If we do not try to help people, the violence will only continue. 
They grow up in this culture and are taught this mentality that in many 
cases is a necessity just to survive. It is especially important in 
racially charged areas like Ferguson where black people are subjected to 
racism every day, from everyone - including the police.
5. No, asshole-ness does not mean you can try to kill someone. But after 
years of being treated like an inferior, and hearing some asshole be a 
racist maybe it's the last straw for some people to fight back (no, there 
is no conclusive evidence that in either case murder was attempted - except 
by the actual murderers). Some people who grew up in the hood mentality 
culture and have a built-up sense of anger and their own racism. Zimmerman 
is a different case than Wilson. Zimmerman was a citizen, a regular guy. In 
Zimmerman's case we have little evidence that suggested Martin actually 
attacked him, and almost none that says he was doing anything with deadly 
force/intent. Wilson was an officer of the law. He is a professional. He 
should NOT lose his temper and NOT be an asshole. I wrote extensively on 
this in a previous post, if you read it. Think objectively. I know it is 
hard working in that dangerous situation and area. But that does not excuse 
a killing. There is very little evidence that says Brown was trying to kill 
him! When he shot Brown, they were out of the car and Brown either had his 
hands up, or was running towards Wilson. Either way, his life was not in 
danger to the point where he should not have fired to wound. Someone being 
an asshole is not an excuse to actually commit murder when you are the only 
one armed and have the option to wound.
6. Yes, it is dangerous to our judicial system, yes, it is dangerous in the 
ghetto, and yes, I don't think Wilson woke up an wanted to be a murderer. 
But our judicial system should be comprised of well-trained, 
mentally-healthy, not racist individuals. We don't want people to die when 
they should live. The danger is stressful and I understand that. But it is 
not enough of an excuse to kill and unarmed man. Wilson not wanting to 
commit murder when he woke up is not an argument and says nothing other 
than it was not planned, which nobody things.
7. If Wilson was being an asshole he was provoking Brown. That's not how a 
police officer, a professional defender of the law, should behave. He made 
a situation worse than it was and created something that escalated to the 
point where he killed an unarmed man.
8. "Brown was an n- word..." What?? That's just a derogatory term derived 
from Spanish for black. It has no definition. One cannot be a nigger or not 
a nigger. That's like saying someone is or is not a cunt. Or someone, by a 
technical definition, is or is not a bitch. That's not how insults and 
derogatory language works. I suppose if you want to be technical he 
qualifies because he is black. But it's not something he can be just 
because he was a criminal. This statement is very racist in itself and with 
your other comments, it seems that you yourself are fairly racist. That 
puts you at a bias in this argument, which shows why you accept slight 
evidence that goes in your favor, while dismissing almost anything that is 
not indisputable if it goes against you. Try to look at things objectively 
here.
8. No, he did not have that right, even if he was provoked (although again, 
I'll remind you not to see them as equals - Wilson, as a professional, has 
a responsibility to try to not be provoked and certainly never to provoke). 
But the only evidence that says he tried to take his gun is Wilson's word. 
That is anything but conclusive. Just because you doubt it is a lie does 
not make it fact, nor does it make it likely. Brown only said that much 
later.
9. Again, your opinion of Brown has no meaning because you don't know him. 
You will cite the robbery video. He was certainly not being terribly 
ruthless and just because someone is a bad person does not mean he is a 
"crazy nut."
10. Stop citing "forensics" and provide a link for the blood smear thing. 
There is nothing that says he charged other than this, which as +Liza 
Tanzawa said, might be explained by his body falling forward. If even such 
evidence exists. Freaked out by the gun going off in the car? He SHOT the 
gun in the car at Brown on purpose. Pointed the gun at Wilson? Again, 
Wilson is the ONLY one saying this. If Brown had the gun, how did Wilson 
recover his weapon? Forensics support that theory? Forensics couldn't 
support that theory. If you disagree, please provide your sources.
11. Black racism towards white? Whites created this racism! It's our own 
fault! And it doesn't help when ignorant conservative perpetuate it. Blacks 
also perpetuate it, but as I said, we need to address it and help them. 
Only when we lift people out of ghettos and help them become productive 
members of a safe society will we bad able to combat racism from both ends.

Now, if you disagree with what I say, please respond to my points directly 
with facts supported by evidence. I am happy to respond in turn and provide 
my own evidence for anything you disagree with. But please refrain from 
simply giving a single paragraph giving the same overview and citing 
evidence you don't provide. Don't just give your opinionated view without 
supporting facts. Lay out the facts, deal with them objectively, and 
support them. I can defend any of my points that you have a problem with.
comments.author: battlebots1

comments.text:
+battlebots1 Listen, I'm sure you mean well...and I talk to liberals, 
they're nice people and they mean well...but they often buy the liberal 
media bullshit...I studied this story and Travon Martin too...and Obama is 
a phony...and Sharpton too...and I know the 'hood mentality (black ghetto 
violence)...and the cop may've been an asshole, yes...and Zimmerman, 
too....but it doesn't mean Travon or Brown had a right to retaliate with 
attempted murder...this is dangerous to our judicial system and the 
police....cops have a tough job in the ghetto...and I don't think Wilson 
got up that day and said I want to shoot a black kid...he was maybe being 
an asshole and even hit him in the ass with his door....cops can be 
assholes...he might've used the n...word (and frankly, Brown was the 
n....word if you see the video of him stealing the cigars and assaulting 
the store owner--you can google that)...but it doesn't give him the right 
to punch the cop and try to take his gun....I doubt this is a cover-up 
lie...I think Brown was a crazy nut...and as Brown ran at him the cop rapid 
fired to bring him down, as he was already freaked out by the gun going off 
in the car after Brown punched him and tried to take the gun and maybe did 
point the gun at Wilson when they were wrestling. Forensics support that 
story. Sorry. I'm fed up with blacks racism towards white...I lived in 
Miami-Dade and Broward, I know.
comments.author: Martin Rodgers

comments.text:
Like I said, I haven't seen the evidence about the blood trail, but that 
could be one possible explanation. But remember, look at the facts how they 
present themselves, not how you want them to be. Personally, I don't think 
there is enough evidence to say either way. Most likely they were both 
being belligerent. He should not have been shot, and the officer should 
receive some punishment (even if the very worst had happened and he was 
charging him, he should have used non-lethal force), but I don't think we 
should put the officer to the death penalty or life in jail. Nothing that 
extreme.
comments.author: battlebots1

comments.text:
That is very thorough, thanks. I thought it more likely Brown was falling 
forward when shot that time, rather than charging?
comments.author: Liza Tanzawa

comments.text:
+Liza Tanzawa +Martin Rodgers There was blood in the car, on his uniform, 
and on the gun. Yes. He also shot him in the car, hitting his arm. Brown 
ran away, and put up his hands. The officer then shot him. There are 
several important things to consider:
1. What was the instigation in the first place? Wilson was trying to get 
out of the car, and Brown shoved him back in. Why? What made Brown become 
so violent? Now, to be fair, Wilson has never been charged with anything 
before. His record is clean. But his life has been troubled and tragic, and 
his two police assignments have been in racially charged areas. It would 
seem that a likely answer is that it was a racially-charged comment, or one 
that could be interpreted as such, in a town that is so racially charged.
2. You would grab at the gun too, if you were a minority used to racist 
officers and in the situation. Sure, it was a stupid thing to do (run at 
the officer getting out of the car), but it must be scary to know that 
there are people in power and with guns and your experience has shown that 
they will assault or provoke you for little to no reason.
3. After being shot and grabbing at the gun, it seems that Brown realized 
his awful mistakes and that the best option was to trust in the law. If he 
was going to keep fighting, he wouldn't have ran away. He had 
already been shot - I'm sure he was not eager to charge the cop who had 
just proven he would shoot. Wilson had just been attacked. In addition to 
his upset personal life and possible racist views, this could have led him 
to shoot Brown. 
4. One more thing to consider: Brown charging again. If seems very unlikely 
that he would attack again, but let's consider the possibility. You cite 
forensic evidence of blood saying that he was charging. I saw no evidence 
of that in my research. However, it is possible, and as I said above, if it 
did happen it was probably provoked. It is very easy to imagine Wilson 
saying something that would provoke another attack.
5. Lastly: what if Brown instigated it? What if he said racially charged 
comments or made a rude gesture towards the cop car? It is very possible, 
as we all know. In that case, Wilson should not have engaged. He is an 
officer of the law. It is his job to be the bigger man and not react 
violently. I know it is hard. I know he had his own stress and troubles. 
But objectively, a police officer should not respond to comments or 
gestures.
comments.author: battlebots1

comments.text:
+Aimee McKim He wasn't resisting arrest. You can see him dying on video, 
face down in the dust with his hands cuffed behind his back saying over and 
over, panicking and weaker each time, "I can't breathe." They could have 
sat him up or at least turned him on his side, but they kept him face down 
in the asthma-inducing dirty sidewalk, compressing his lungs with his large 
body weight, until they killed him. To me it was cold-blooded murder of an 
unarmed, middle-aged, obese, diabetic, asthmatic civilian by a heartless 
pack of human hyenas. Utterly disgusting. Horrifying. It could have 
happened to ANY medically fragile older adult in their custody. It's not 
about what Garner did or did not do. Not one police officer on-video 
appears to care even a tiny bit whether Garner lives or dies.

comments.text:
+tatewaki11 No. You can't just make up facts. This is the point. I don't 
have an agenda like you. I want the truth without people like you making up 
fantasies. From the medical report on the NPR website.

The postmortem report found a gunshot entrance wound on the vertex of 
Brown's scalp. There was an entrance wound in his central forehead, with a 
corresponding exit wound in his right jaw. Another ENTRANCE wound was in 
his upper right chest and one in his lateral right chest. There was an 
entrance wound in the upper ventral right arm, along with a corresponding 
exit wound on the upper dorsal right arm. There was also a gunshot entrance 
wound on the dorsal right forearm, along with a corresponding exit wound of 
the medial ventral right forearm.

http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/11/25/366575509/ferguson-documents-the-physical-evidence

The worst part is you are either lying or heard it from a third party and 
took it as fact. THAT is disgraceful.

I MEAN what a level off stupidity and arrogance you display. AND with such 
confidence you spout it. Truly amazing.
